thread.title: Two Indians in connection with German Bakery blast, Indian Mujahideen arrested in Saudi
thread.title_full: Two Indians in connection with German Bakery blast, Indian Mujahideen arrested in Saudi

author: Nithya Nair | India.com News Desk
title: Two Indians in connection with German Bakery blast, Indian Mujahideen arrested in Saudi
text:
Two Indians in connection with German Bakery blast, Indian Mujahideen arrested in Saudi By India.com News Desk on October 9, 2015 at 8:56 PM Comments 
Two Indians wanted in German Bakery blast in Pune were detained in Saudi Arabia, reported Indian Express. The accused have been identified as Abu Sufiyan alias Asadullah Khan and Zainul Abideen alias Zahid Sheikh. The two are likely to be deported soon. Sufiyan has allegedly participated in terrorists meeting in 2011-12. He is believed to have connection with terrorists in Bengaluru. 
They also reportedly have alleged links with Lakshar-e-Taiba. Several accused in the Pune blast case are suspected to be hiding in Saudi Arabia. The case is being pursued by the National Investigation Agency (NIA). Sufiyan was detained eight months ago and agencies were trying to get orders for his deportation. While investigating for explosives supply chain for the Indian Mujahideen (IM), Bengaluru police uncovered Zainul Abideenâ€™s involvement in the blast. 
The main supplier of explosives to the IM, Syed Afaque is alleged to have received explosives in the Pune German Bakery blast from Sufityan. He was detained 20 days ago and is likely to be deported in a week. (Also Read- Indian Mujahideen planned strikes during festivals: Police) 
The German blast occurred on February 13, 2010 in Pune, Maharashtra which killed 17 people and left 60 injured. An Italian woman, two Sudanese students and and Iranian student were among the dead. RDX explosives used in the blast were later recovered by the police. The lone victim in the bombing is currently behind the bars.
